data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: You very rarely need to do anything to them. It's not like a cable brake that needs occasional adjustment as the pads wear and the cable stretches. You will eventually have to reset the pistons when you replace pads which is very easy, and very occasionally bleed your brakes which isn't as hard as people think and not an expensive job for a bike shop. You shouldn't have to bleed brakes more than once a year. If using dot fluid (sram) you must flush your brake fluid once a year in addition to bleeding. All in all hydraulic brakes seem scary because there's fluid but in reality it's way less maintenance than cable brakes long term.

data.text: I have one bike with hydrolic brakes and one with mechanical. I've never taken the hydrolic one touring, but it was my main ride for the first year I had it. In spite of putting more miles on it, I had to mess with the brakes less than my mechanical brakes. I feel like with my mechanicals, I have to recenter them, and they seem to get glazed and need new pads before the old ones are worn. My hydrolics required me learning to do bleeds and buying a couple of new tools, but once they were set up, I didn't need to touch them until they started squealing when the pads had completely worn out, after about a year. I'd see how you feel about them. You can always swap to mechanicals, but unless you're traveling at length in the middle of nowhere, I wouldn't expect it to be a big deal.
